Hi Oliver,

Happy to hear that you like the paper!

I think for initial tes=
ts I let evolution run for around 200 generations
and that also did not hel=
p the unseeded treatment to find a solution.
Also, the fitness always remai=
ned very low (around 24) and never showed any
signs of improvement.

I thin=
k this is another one of those domains were deception plays a key
role; if =
you do not already start somewhere in the vicinity of the final
solution
yo=
u will not get there with an objective-based performance measure.
Especiall=
y discovering the stepping stones that lead to a network that has
the right=
 self-organizing dynamics is probably very hard.  It would be
interesting t=
o also try novelty search in this context since it has been
very helpful at=
 discovering plastic neural networks in the past (
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/=
papers/risi_ab10.pdf)

Cheers,
Sebastian



On Tue, Apr 29, 2014 at 2:59 AM=

> a topic I'm very =

>
> I have a question about the unseeded treatment: did you =
try longer
> evolutionary runs to see if it would eventually find a solutio=
n?

>>> Kenneth Stanley and I are pleased to a=
nnounce our new GECCO paper (to
>>> appear), "Guided Self-Organization in I=
ndirectly Encoded and Evolving
>>> Topographic Maps"
>>>
>>> *PDF: *http://=
eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf
>>>
>>> This paper introduces the =
idea that HyperNEAT can be seeded with a
>>> lateral inhibitory connectivit=
y pattern, which then allows the weights from
>>> the inputs to the hidden =
layer of an ANN to self-organize to form a genuine
>>> topographic map of t=
he input space. The benefit of this new approach is
>>> that the initial se=
ed can be evolved further to accelerate the
>>> self-organizing process and=
 to bias it towards a specific target
>>> configuration. An interesting imp=
lication is that enabling HyperNEAT to
>>> capture this key feature of natu=
ral systems might now allow us to evolve
>>> architectures resembling deep =
learning networks, SOMs, or other
>>> self-organizing processes that also r=
ely on unsupervised learning processes.
>>>
>>> *Abstract: *An important ph=
enomenon seen in many areas of biological
>>> brains and recently in deep l=
earning architectures is a process known as
>>> self-organization. For exam=
ple, in the primary visual cortex, color and
>>> orientation maps develop b=
ased on lateral inhibitory connectivity patterns
>>> and Hebbian learning d=
ynamics. These topographic maps, which are found in
>>> all sensory systems=
, are thought to be a key factor in enabling abstract
>>> cognitive represe=
ntations. This paper shows for the first time that the
>>> Hypercube-based =
NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (HyperNEAT) method
>>> can be seede=
d to begin evolution  with such lateral connectivity, enabling
>>> genuine =
self-organizing dynamics. The proposed approach draws on
>>> HyperNEAT's ab=
ility to generate a pattern of weights across the
>>> connectivity of an ar=
tificial neural network (ANN) based on a function of
>>> its geometry. Vali=
dating this approach, the afferent weights of an ANN
>>> self-organize in t=
his paper to form a genuine topographic map of the input
>>> space for a si=
mple line orientation task. Most interestingly, this seed can
>>> then be e=
volved further, providing a method to guide the self-organization
>>> of we=
ights in a specific way, much as evolution likely guided the
>>> self-organ=
izing trajectories of biological brains.
>>>
>>> Cheers,
>>> Sebastian
>>>

ery hard. =C2=A0It would be interesting to also try novelty search in this =

<br><div><div>On Apr 28, 2014, at 3:47 AM, =
Sebastian Risi <<a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." target=3D"_b=
lank">sebastian.risi@...</a>> wrote:</div><br><blockquote type=3D"=
cite">












 
<div>
<span>=C2=A0</span>



    <div><div><br></div><=
div dir=3D"ltr">Kenneth Stanley and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO=
 paper (to appear), "Guided Self-Organization in Indirectly Encoded an=
d Evolving Topographic Maps"<br><br><b>PDF: </b><a href=3D"http://eple=
x.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf=
.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf</a><br>



<br>This paper introduces the idea =
that HyperNEAT can be seeded with a lateral inhibitory connectivity pattern=
, which then allows the weights from the inputs to the hidden layer=C2=A0of=
 an ANN to self-organize to form a genuine topographic map of the input=C2=
=A0space. The benefit of this new approach is that the initial seed can=C2=
=A0be evolved further to accelerate the self-organizing process and to=C2=
=A0bias it towards a specific target configuration. An interesting implicat=
ion=C2=A0is that enabling HyperNEAT to capture this key feature of=C2=A0nat=
ural systems might now allow us to evolve architectures resembling=C2=A0dee=
p learning networks, SOMs, or other self-organizing processes that also rel=
y on unsupervised learning processes.<br>



<br><b>Abstract: </b>An import=
ant phenomenon seen in many areas of biological brains and recently in deep=
 learning architectures is a process known as self-organization. For exampl=
e, in the primary visual cortex, color and orientation maps develop based o=
n lateral inhibitory connectivity patterns and Hebbian learning dynamics. T=
hese topographic maps, which are found in all sensory systems, are thought =
to be a key factor in enabling abstract cognitive representations. This pap=
er shows for the first time that the Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution of Augm=
enting Topologies (HyperNEAT) method can be seeded to begin evolution =C2=
=A0with such lateral connectivity, enabling genuine self-organizing dynamic=
s. The proposed approach draws on HyperNEAT's ability to generate a pat=
tern of weights across the connectivity of an artificial neural network (AN=
N) based on a function of its geometry. Validating this approach, the affer=
ent weights of an ANN self-organize in this paper to form a genuine topogra=
phic map of the input space for a simple line orientation task. Most intere=
stingly, this seed can then be evolved further, providing a method to guide=
 the self-organization of weights in a specific way, much as evolution like=
ly guided the self-organizing trajectories of biological brains.<br>



<br=
>Cheers,<br>Sebastian<br><br>--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Professo=
r <br>IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300=
 Copenhagen, Denmark<br>email: <a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." =
target=3D"_blank">sebastian.risi@...</a>, web: <a href=3D"http://www.=
